##  {.smaller}

::: columns
::: {.column width="65%"}
**Do species-level datasets identified with DNA-metabarcoding reveal patterns in macroinvertebrates not observed in family-level datasets?**

</br>

![](https://i.ibb.co/BgRrpzq/Screenshot-2024-06-12-at-1-01-29-PM.png){fig-align="left" width="1200"}
:::

::: {.column width="35%"}
```{mermaid}
%%| fig-responsive: false
%%| fig-height: 7
%%| fig-width: 5
  flowchart TB
    AF[Upstream\nForest cover] -->|positive response| F((Family:\nLeptoceridae))
    linkStyle 0 color:green;
    F --> |Different| C(Species #1:\nTriplectides\naustralicus)
    linkStyle 1 color:red;
    F -->|No response| A(Species #2:\nLectrides\nvarians)
    linkStyle 2 color:orange;
    F --> |Similar| B(Species #3:\nNotalina\nbifara)
    linkStyle 3 color:green;



```
:::
:::

-   Historically, most macroinvertebrate ecological knowledge is is drawn from family-level data sorted by hand.
-   Species-level data from DNA metabarcoding suggests family-level data under-appreciates how macroinvertebrates will respond to changing landscapes.
